questions.text: A mother brings her child with features of multiple teeth and a soft skull. On examination, the child is able to touch his both shoulder joints. Ans. C. Cleidocranial dysostosis

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their mother due to pain in the right hip and difficulty walking. Physical examination reveals no significant external abnormalities. questions.explanation:

  • • affects older adults
  • • abnormal bone remodelling

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the pediatric department by her mother, who is concerned about the child's delayed developmental milestones, hypermobility, and frequent dislocations of her shoulders and knees. Upon examination, the pediatrician also notes decreased visual acuity and suspects a condition related to a protein defect with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. Which of the following statements about the suspected disease is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is due to the mutation in the gene responsible for collagen

options.label: B
options.text: Superotemporal dislocation of lens can be seen

options.label: C
options.text: Child will present with features of tall stature and joint hypermobility

options.label: D
options.text: Can be associated with Cardiac abnormalities

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. It is due to the mutation in the gene responsible for Collagen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B: Superotemporal dislocation of the lens: This is true for Marfan syndrome . Lens dislocation (ectopia lentis) is a common ocular manifestation, with the lens typically dislocating in a superotemporal direction. Other Ocular manifestations can include near-sightedness and retinal detachment.
  • • Option B: Superotemporal dislocation of the lens:
  • • true for Marfan syndrome
  • • Option C: Tall stature and joint hypermobility: Patients with Marfan syndrome often present with a tall stature , long limbs , and joint hypermobility , which are characteristic features of the condition. May include a curved spine, and chest deformities such as pectus excavatum. Patients may also experience joint hypermobility.
  • • Option C: Tall stature and joint hypermobility:
  • • present with a tall stature
  • • long limbs
  • • joint hypermobility
  • • Option D: Cardiac abnormalities: Marfan syndrome can be associated with various cardiac issues , most notably aortic dilatation and dissection (aortic aneurysms), which are significant causes of morbidity and mortality in affected individuals.
  • • Option D: Cardiac abnormalities:
  • • associated with various cardiac issues
  • • notably aortic dilatation
  • • dissection
  • • Early diagnosis and careful monitoring are crucial to managing the condition and preventing severe complications. Treatment options focus on symptom management and surgical interventions if necessary.

questions.text: A 2-month-old male infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to irregular bowel movements, abdominal distension, and bilious vomiting. The mother reports a delayed passage of meconium. Pediatric examination reveals a distended abdomen with visible peristaltic waves, and a rectal examination shows an empty rectum. questions.explanation:

  • • not cause the symptoms of delayed meconium passage

  • • B. Duodenal atresia:
  • • bilious vomiting shortly after birth
  • • "double bubble" sign on X-ray
  • • Option D: Jejunal atresia: Would present earlier in the neonatal period with symptoms of intestinal obstruction and does not typically involve delayed meconium passage or a transition zone in the rectosigmoid area.

  • • D: Jejunal atresia:
  • • present earlier in the neonatal period

questions.text: A mother brings her 24-day-old male infant to the clinic with a 4-day history of vomiting. The infant appears dehydrated and irritable upon physical examination. questions.text: A 27-day-old male infant is brought to the clinic by his mother due to episodes of projectile vomiting. Physical examination reveals a palpable mass on palpation/auscultation (P/A) with observable peristaltic waves moving from left to the right side. Ultrasonography shows a "target sign," and blood tests indicate hypokalemia with acidic urine. Considering the clinical presentation and ultrasound findings, which medication taken prenatally is most associated with the development of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Erythromycin

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Penicillin: There is no established link between prenatal penicillin exposure and the development of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis .
  • • Option
  • • A. Penicillin:
  • • no established link
  • • prenatal penicillin exposure
  • • development of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
  • • Option B. Dexamethasone: This medication is not typically associated with HPS . It is a corticosteroid often used prenatally to accelerate lung maturity but does not have a known causal relationship with HPS.
  • • Option
  • • B. Dexamethasone:
  • • not typically associated with HPS
  • • Option C. Lithium: Lithium use during pregnancy is associated with congenital cardiac anomalies , particularly Ebstein anomaly, rather than HPS.
  • • Option
  • • C. Lithium:
  • • during pregnancy
  • • congenital cardiac anomalies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An infant presenting with non-bilious projectile vomiting , palpable abdominal mass , hypokalemia , and aciduria , alongside ultrasound evidence of the "target sign," is indicative of Infantile Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (IHPS). Maternal erythromycin intake is a risk factor for IHPS . Diagnosis is primarily clinical, supported by ultrasonography findings of increased pyloric muscle thickness. While IHPS is a medical emergency, the definitive treatment is surgical via Ramstedt pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl named Rohini is brought to the clinic by her father due to a history of frequent falls.
